description: Fundamentals of Statistics. Descriptive statistics and simple linear regression. Emphasis is on the development of statistical thinking and applications are directed towards the behavioral sciences, especially psychology, and medicine. Topics include probability, statistical inference, hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.
name: INTRODUCTORY STATISTICS

values.comments:
Statistics 111 introduces the Fundamentals of Statistics, which include descriptive statistics and simple linear regression. The class emphasizes the development of statistical thinking. Applications of statistical thinking are directed towards the behavioral sciences, especially psychology, and medicine. Topics include probability, statistical inference, hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.

Students with no prior exposure to statistics generally found this course to be more difficult than expected, one student stating that “for someone who hadn’t taken stat in high school” he had “trouble keeping up.”  This is because, as a few students describe, the content was presented in a “fast-paced” manner under the assumption of some prior experience, like AP statistics.  However, others found that even though some concepts were difficult, “the “surveys and statistics learned are very applicable to a lot of things emphasized at Penn.”  For those who had encountered statistics before, the content was described as “easy,” but what made it difficult to some was the way the textbook complicated information that should have been straightforward.  Two separate students were dismayed to find the same content was easier to understand in their AP stat classes than as presented in the college-level textbook that was “all over the place” in explaining concepts. The most difficult aspect for a few students was the JMP software, and students felt the content of the course should have focused more on helping students understand this “unintuitive program.” 

A majority of students generally found Professor Wyner to be a “knowledgeable professor” who, one student felt, “kept the class fun and lively.”  Another student stated that “Professor Wyner adeptly communicates a somewhat dour subject” and that his “enthusiasm and passion for teaching” was “contagious.” Several students agreed that Professor Wyner was an engaging instructor who “certainly made the topic relatable.”  A few students did note, though, that Professor Wyner’s teaching style was “unclear” at times and that his lecture slides appeared outdated.  Some felt Professor Wyner could be “harsh in answering questions” during lecture time.  However, a lot of students enjoyed Professor Wyner’s professor/student lunches arranged at Pod and found him “very approachable” during office hours.

A discrepancy existed between exams and class work; one student noted “exams were much harder than lecture content.”  Another student agreed, stating that “the exams for this course were extremely difficult.” The TAs were “unable to explain the problems” assigned for homework or on exams, and some students found outside tutors early on.  The workload for this class is described by most as “heavy,” due to weekly homework assignments that are “extremely time-consuming” and at times “tedious.”  A majority of students wished that homework was worth a greater percentage than 20% to better “acknowledge the hours of work put into homework.”  Students generally agreed that the final carried too much weight.  The only official prerequisite for this course is high school algebra.  This course is highly recommended for majors, but only moderately recommended for non-majors.

This course is a recitation for STAT111, Fundamentals of Statistics, which
focuses on descriptive statistics and simple linear regression. Emphasis is on the
development of statistical thinking and applications are directed towards the behavioral
sciences, especially psychology, and medicine. Topics include probability, statistical
inference, hypothesis testing and confidence intervals. High school algebra is the
prerequisite for this course.
Overall, students felt that the recitation was “interesting, but difficult.” Opinions
surrounding the effectiveness of the recitation were split; some students found the
recitation to be a great help while others thought that the recitation was disorganized.
Some of the students complained that Mr. Rising was disorganized. One student
mentioned that he took a long time to grade and return assignments and another described
Mr. Rising as condescending towards the students. A couple students however felt that he
clarified the material and that “he was willing to do whatever students needed to
improve.”
The students took this course as a recitation for STAT 111. This course was
heavily dependent on problem solving. In terms of grading, reviews were mostly
negative. One student mentioned that Mr. Rising was an unfair grader, explaining, “There
were multiple times when [he/she] received higher grades than my peers who had the
same answers.”

Statistics 111 covers basic ideas of probability, statistics and statistical methods for the behavioral sciences, especially psychology. Topics include probability, statistical inference, hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals. 

Overall, This course received positive reviews. Students commented that they “learned a lot.” However, some students did express that there was just too much information to learn in a short period of time. 

Professor Szabat received overwhelmingly positive reviews. Some said she “was one of the nicest professors at Penn” and others commented that she was “enthusiastic” and got students “interested in a subject that is seemingly boring.” 

Students complained that the course pack should be better organized. Some also said that key formulas should be provided in a more accessible manner.
